listing_description:
When the Lights Come On: Queer Nightlife as Emergent Space, curated by Hannah Turpin, brings together local, national, and international artists reflecting on their experiences of queer nightlife. listing_description:

Tanner and his wife Sarah had four children, including Henry Ossawa Tanner, who was the first Black painter to gain international acclaim, as well as Halle Tanner Dillon Johnson, one of the first Black women physicians.

listing_description:
La Voz que Soy, or The Voice I Am, is Afro-Latina soprano Zuly Inirio‚Äôs reinterpretation of the 1958 French opera La voix humaine. This multidisciplinary performance-in-progress uses the opera‚Äôs original framework‚Äîrevisiting her past love through a final phone call‚Äîto explore colonialism, double consciousness, Black womanhood, and the African diaspora‚Äôs legacy. By intertwining these issues with the opera‚Äôs original themes of loss, assimilation, and the cost of self-preservation, La Voz que Soy highlights Zuly‚Äôs journey as a Black Latinx woman. The piece invites audiences into meaningful conversations about identity, resilience, and the shared experiences that connect us across diverse backgrounds.

title: PulpFest 2025
teaser: Thu., Aug. 7, 9-12 a.m., Fri., Aug. 8, 9-12 a.m. and Sat., Aug. 9, 9 a.m.
location: Doubletree by Hilton Hotel Pittsburgh - Cranberry
listing_description:
For more than 50 years, PulpFest has celebrated mystery, adventure, science fiction, and other popular fiction. The pulp magazines of the early twentieth century - cheaply-priced all-fiction magazines printed on pulpwood paper - were the vessel where the hardboiled detective, science fiction, and sword and sorcery genres developed and flourished. The pulps gave us Buck Rogers, Conan the Barbarian, Cthulhu, Doc Savage, Hopalong Cassidy, John Carter of Mars, Sam Spade, The Shadow, Tarzan, Zorro, and many other pop culture icons.
